title: Why is strict naturalism-the idea that natural forces alone exist-so popular among scientists? - Quora

response.answer_text: By ‘forces’, I think you mean ‘things that control behaviour of things’, rather than a strict physics definition of forces. Science is the attempt to reduce everything to causes. But the dilemma is that only data and causes discernible by man are available for consideration, by the definition of science. In other words, science is naturalistic by nature, and therefore it is geared to looking for and finding naturalistic answers. That’s why scientists tend to venerate naturalism. It’s likely to be inherent in their worldview, because it’s how they are trained to think. That’s not necessarily wrong, and the hard sciences have achieved a lot. But it is worth being aware of the potential limitations of this method and outlook. otherwise, like many, we may get blindsided by the very word ‘science’. Maths, and Godel’s incompleteness theorems in particular, point us to the fact that science pursued in this way is actually not entirely logical! Godel proved that for any set of self-consistent axioms, there are statements not governed by these axioms, and that the system itself cannot prove that the system itself is consistent. Stated more simply, no closed system of axioms is ever logically complete, even if the axioms themselves are self-consistent. There’s a rather strong hint in here that the scientific method, naturalistic reductionism, is a fatally flawed exercise if your goal is to bring it to final completion. Stated another way, science as we perform it is not a good vehicle on which to arrive at final truth. Stated yet another way, good science is possible, perfect and complete science almost certainly isn’t possible. Regardless of how long and hard you pursue it. Here I’m talking about ‘hard’ science, with attempts made to conform reality to a concise mathematical model. A lot of science is nowhere near as logically rigorous as this even, and represents simply a possible narrative over a set of data. That data is often patchy. Hard Darwinism springs to mind.

The idea is to try to explain something with as few loose ends as possible. In general, explanations that include “invisible people” are way more complicated than explanations that only include “invisible forces”. Forces are simple — you measure a few numbers, make a few definitions, and you’re done. But with invisible people, you have to explain who they are, what they want, what they did, how they did what they did, why they are invisible, how invisible people exist in the first place — there are a million loose ends. For example, I lose my keys, I look around the house and I find them on the counter. The simplest explanation is that I had them and I put them down and then forgot all about it. It’s consistent with the evidence and it has no loose ends. A more complicated explanation would be “somebody took my keys and put them here”. But now we have a bunch of loose ends: Who took them? Why? When did they do this? How did they get the keys in the first place? So I have a lot more work to do to finish this explanation. I’ve got to interview potential suspects, explain their motivation, prove they had the opportunity, and so on. An even more complicated explanation would be “the ghost of my father took my keys and put them here.” Now you have a huge number of loose ends — you have to explain what a ghost is, what it’s made of, how it does things, why it does things, and so on. Chances are, if I worked for the rest of my life on this explanation, I would never finish it. Naturalism is not some kind of absolute law or some kind quasi-religious faith that scientists have. It’s a heuristic. A rule of thumb. It’s related to other guidelines like Occam’s Razor (“the simplest explanation is probably right”) or Parsimony (“keep your answer as short as possible”). Science doesn’t say that explanations with invisible people are wrong — it only says, look I have this explanation here that is plausible and simple, so let’s work with that (at least until somebody finds a way to show it won’t work). And if you think about it, science uses a lot of invisible things — gravity, for example, isn’t a “real” thing. What’s real is the way things fall. The “invisible spring” of gravity is metaphysical — the philosopher’s word for “things that you can’t see or touch but we believe in them anyway.” So science doesn’t have a rule “no invisible powers!” — it’s not perfect naturalistic. It just prefers simplicity to mystery.
